subSense.example:
The President's guards wres-
tled with the demonstrators

subSense.def:
to twist from side
to side
subSense.example:
The baby wriggled in her fa-
ther's arms

The worm wriggled back
into the soil

body.subSense:
to twist something, espe-
cially to get water out of it ć Wring the
face cloth (dry) after you have used it. ć
He wrung out his shirt before putting it
to dry. (NOTE: wrings -wringing -
wrung /r ŋ/)

subSense.def: a fold in the skin
subSense.example:
She had an operation to remove wrin-
kles round her eyes

subSense.def:
full of
lines or creases

the joint between the
arm and the hand

to put words or num-
bers on paper etc. using a pen, pencil,
computer etc
subSense.example:
She wrote the address
on the back of an envelope

Write the
reference number at the top of the letter

subSense.def:
to write a letter and send it to some-
one
subSense.example: She writes to me twice a week

Don't forget to write as soon as you get
to your hotel

body.subSense:
3. to be the author of a
book or music etc. ć He wrote a book on
keeping tropical fish. ć Didn't you know
she used to write for the 'Sunday
Times'? (NOTE: writes -writing -
wrote /rəυt/ -written / rt(ə)n/)

subSense.def:
a person who writes
books or articles

something which
is written
subSense.example:
Please don't phone, reply in
writing

Put everything in writing,
then you have a record of what has been
done

subSense.def:
which has
been put in writing

participle of
write
not correct
subSense.example:
He gave three wrong answers and failed
the test

That's not the right time, is it?
-No, the clock is wrong

You've come
to the wrong house -there's no one
called Jones living here

I must have
pressed the wrong button

subSense.def: not suitable
subSense.example:
You came just at the wrong time, when
we were bathing the children

She was
wearing the wrong sort of dress for a
wedding

subSense.def: not working properly
subSense.example:
There is something wrong with the tele-
vision

subSense.def: morally bad
subSense.example:
It's wrong to
talk like that about her

Cheating in
exams is wrong

subSense.def:
making someone
worried
badly
subSense.example:
Everything
went wrong yesterday

She spelt my
name wrong

subSense.def: not correctly

the twenty-fourth letter of
the alphabet, between W and Y

body.subSense:
1. a multiplication sign ć 3 x 3 = 9.
(NOTE: say 'three times three equals
nine')

2. showing size ć The table top is
24 x 36cm. (NOTE: say 'twenty-four by
thirty-six centimetres')

subSense.def:
the Roman numeral for ten
or tenth

a type of radia-
tion that doctors use for taking photo-
graphs of the inside of your body
subSense.example:
The
X-ray examination showed the key was
inside the baby's stomach

The X-ray
department is closed for lunch

subSense.def:
a pho-
tograph taken with X-rays
subSense.example:
The X-ray
showed that the bone was broken in two
places

They will take an X-ray of his
leg

She was sent to hospital for an X-
ray

subSense.def:
to take an X-ray photograph
of someone
subSense.example:
There are six patients
waiting to be X-rayed

They X-rayed
my leg to see if it was broken

subSense.def:
the twenty-fifth letter of
the alphabet, between X and Z

a sailing boat used for
pleasure and sport

a large comforta-
ble boat with a motor
subSense.example:
She spent her
holiday on a yacht in the Mediterrane-
an

subSense.def:
a measurement of
length, equal to 0.914 metres
subSense.example:
The po-
lice station is only yards away from
where the fight took place

Can you
move your car a couple of yards as it is
blocking the entrance to our garage?

subSense.def:
an area of concrete at the back or side of
a house
subSense.example: We keep our bikes in the yard

subSense.def:
a long piece of wool
used in knitting or weaving
subSense.example:
She sells
yarn from the wool of her sheep

subSense.def:
to open your mouth
wide and breathe in and out deeply
when you are tired or bored
subSense.example:
He went
on speaking for so long that half the
people at the meeting started yawning
or started to yawn

subSense.def: yes

a period of time lasting
twelve months, from January 1st to De-
cember 31st
subSense.example:
Columbus discovered
America in the year 1492

Great cele-
brations which took place in the year
2000

Last year we did not have any
holiday

Next year she's going on hol-
iday in Australia

The weather was
very bad for most of the year
subSense.re:
all year
round working or open for the whole
year ć The museum is open all year
round

subSense.def:
a period of twelve months
from a particular time
subSense.example:
We spent five
years in Hong Kong

He died two hun-
dred years ago today

She'll be eleven
years old tomorrow

How many years
have you been working for the compa-
ny

subSense.def: to shout very loudly
subSense.example:
The
policeman yelled to her to get out of the
way

subSense.def:
of a colour like
that of the sun or of gold
subSense.example:
His new car
is bright yellow

She's wearing yellow
sandals

At this time of year the fields
are full of yellow flowers

subSense.def:
the
colour of the sun or gold
subSense.example:
Do you have
any hats of a lighter yellow than this
one

subSense.def:
a word showing that you
agree with someone, accept something,
or give permission for something
subSense.example:
They asked her if she wanted to come
and she said 'yes'

Anyone want more
coffee? -Yes, please

You don't like
living in London? -Yes I do!

Didn't
you work in Scotland at one time? -Yes,
I did

I need a clear answer -is it
'yes' or 'no'

subSense.def:
the
day before today
subSense.example:
Yesterday was
March 1st so today must be the 2nd
She came to see us yesterday evening

subSense.def:
now, before now, or until
now
subSense.example: Has the manager arrived yet?
I haven't seen her yet this morning

Don't throw the newspaper away -I ha-
ven't read it yet

subSense.def: however
subSense.example:
He's very small and yet he can kick a
ball a long way

It was starting to
snow, and yet he went out without a
coat

subSense.def:
the quantity of a crop or
a product produced from a plant or from
an area of land
subSense.example:
What is the normal
yield per hectare?

subSense.def:
to produce
a result
subSense.example:
Their researches finally yield-
ed the information they were looking for

subSense.def: to produce a crop or a product
subSense.example:
This
variety of rice can yield up to 2 tonnes
per hectare

The North Sea oil depos-
its yield 100,000 barrels a month

subSense.def:
to
do or agree to do something that you
have been trying not to do

the yellow part inside an
egg

referring to
someone being spoken to
subSense.example:
Are you
ready?

You look tired, you should rest
a bit

If I give you my address will you
give me yours?
Hello, how are you?
Are you both keeping well?

body.subSense:
2. referring
to anyone ć You never know when you
might need a penknife. ć You have to be
very tall to be a policeman. (NOTE: You
is both singular and plural.)

subSense.def: not old
subSense.example:
She's
very young, she's only six
He became

Minister when he was still a
young man

My little brother's much
younger than me or than I am

In the
afternoon there are TV programmes for
very young children

This is where
your Daddy lived when he was young

subSense.def: young animals or birds
subSense.example:
Animals
fight to protect their young

subSense.def:
a young per-
son
subSense.example:
My grandparents don't under-
stand today's youngsters

subSense.def: belonging to you
subSense.example:
I
hope you didn't forget to bring your
toothbrush

This letter is for your
brother

subSense.def: belonging to you
subSense.example: This is my car -where's yours?

My
car's in the garage, can I borrow yours

subSense.def:
relating to
'you' as a subject
subSense.example:
Why do you wash
the car yourself, when you could easily
take it to the car wash?

Watch out for
the broken glass -you might hurt your-
self

I hope you are all going to enjoy
yourselves
subSense.note:
NOTE: The plural is your-
selves.

subSense.def: a young man
subSense.example:
Gangs of youths were causing trouble in
the village

A youth, aged 16, was ar-
rested for possessing drugs

subSense.def:
a period
when you are young, especially the time
between being a child and being an
adult
subSense.example:
In his youth he was a great trav-
eller

I haven't done that since the
days of my youth

subSense.def:
the last and twenty-
sixth letter of the alphabet

to hit or kill
someone

body.subSense:
2. to shut down the television
using the remote control (NOTE: zaps -
zapping -zapped)

subSense.def: the number 0
subSense.example:
To
make an international call you dial zero
zero (00), followed by the number of the
country

subSense.def:
the temperature at which wa-
ter freezes
subSense.example:
The temperature stayed be-
low zero for days

subSense.def: nothing at all
subSense.example: They lost ten -zero

subSense.def:
used to de-
scribe a line which turns one way, then
the opposite way
subSense.example:
There are zigzag
lines painted at pedestrian crossings to
show that cars must not stop there

subSense.def: an area
subSense.example:
Police cars
are patrolling the inner city zones

subSense.def:
a place where wild ani-

to see them
to go very fast
subSense.example:
Cars
were zooming past me on the motorway.
